text: ...two brothers with a Kiwi dad and American mom, Alex and Mark,
find themselves with a double identity as a result of having two passports.
Having inherited a sense of curiosity, they've traveled around the world
looking for their own origins and those of other peoples.
And it's exactly that which has brought these two brothers, the "Vagabrothers", to live in San Sebastian.
When we came here and we saw a culture as ancient as the Basques', it fascinated us.
Basque culture is as wide as it is deep, and so we came here, got hooked, and decided to stay here
looking deeper into the culture, learning more each day.
You guys make videos about Basque culture, and the last one you did was about San Sebastian Day
...videos for English-speakers, people from America. But what do they think? What feedback have they given you?
Our idea is to explore the world, connect with locals, and in turn inspire other people to do something similar
As we said, our motto is "Explore, connect, and inspire," but in the end our main goal is to create understanding.
We want to understand the world because we realize that every culture, every language is a different perspective.
We think the world is like a big mosaic, made up of many different parts.
But these days, on one side the world is getting smaller - we're all interconnected.
But on the other side, there's a risk of losing many identities.
That's why we think it's so important to talk about cultural identities.
The Basque Country is a good base to start from because here Basque identity is really strong.
And that's a really good thing.
So, we're starting off here. The project is pretty new, but we're hoping to go from here to wherever life takes us.
You know?
All over the world, checking out all the different cultures and identities?
Yeah, that's it.
We're going bit by bit, episode by episode.
How have the Basques taken you in? They usually say that we're quite introverted, but you guys are telling me
that we're all really extroverted, that you just ask a few questions and they open up to you. How's it been for you?
Well, I think that all over the world there's a lot of prejudice. And there are fixed ideas people have about other people.
And in the case of the Basques, if you go to other parts of Spain - I lived in Galicia and we've been all over Spain
And every time we say we live in the Basque Country, there are a few different reactions.
And sometimes we go into bars in towns that are way out in the boonies, deep in the Basque Country.
And people stare at us like, "What the hell are you guys doing here?"
We just shout to them in Basque, "Hey! What's up? We're from California but we live in San Sebastian!"
They totally freak out. They start laughing and they ask us, "What do you want to drink?"
We think this is something that doesn't just happen in the Basque Country - it's universal.
If you're interested in a person or a culture, people are going to be open and try to help you however they can.
So yeah, to travel of course you need money - but you can't buy genuine interest. You have to have that within.
You have to be interested in the world and know that the world is much more than just your perspective.
When you see the moon from the other side of the world, you realize that your "reality" is just one of many.
What has surprised you the most, what have you most enjoyed about Basque culture so far?
For me, the mythology.
"Akelarres" (witchcraft)
Yeah, akelarres...all the festivals that have a pagan, pre-Christian touch
For me it's a super-fascinating subject, and one of the thousand things about the Basque Country that I love.
These days, we're in the era of "globalization," it's really important to know how to navigate between
modernity and keeping alive the roots of our traditions. And I think that in my experience
I've never found a culture that has done such a good job at preserving its traditions while opening itself to the world.
And you guys have already traveled a lot.
Yeah, well, we've been around the block a few times. But so have the Basques - since way back in the day
they were over in Canada exploring the world as fishermen, explorers and merchants
but at the same time, they always come back home to the Basque Country.
